Urgent neuroimaging is required to distinguish ischaemia from haemorrhage and to identify treatable large-vessel occlusion; vascular imaging and cardiac workup look for an embolic source; blood tests assess stroke risk factors, thrombolysis safety, and alternative inflammatory or demyelinating aetiologies; CSF and spinal MRI are reserved for non-vascular diagnoses.

investigations = ["Non-contrast CT brain", "CT angiogram of head and neck", "MRI brain with brainstem-focused sequences and diffusion-weighted imaging", "MR angiogram of intracranial and neck vessels", "ECG", "Continuous cardiac telemetry monitoring", "Transthoracic echocardiogram", "Carotid and vertebral artery duplex ultrasound", "Full blood count", "Urea and electrolytes", "Liver function tests", "Coagulation screen", "Blood glucose", "HbA1c", "Lipid profile", "Erythrocyte sedimentation rate", "C-reactive protein", "Thyroid function tests", "Antinuclear antibody", "Extractable nuclear antigen panel", "Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies", "Aquaporin-4 antibody", "Myelin oligodendrocyte glycoprotein (MOG) antibody", "Lumbar puncture with CSF cell count, protein, glucose, oligoclonal bands and IgG index (after imaging excludes mass effect)", "MRI of whole spinal cord with contrast"]
